bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, May 18, 1953

div1.p: Hench discusses the awarding of Finlay Medals to various yellow fever experiment participants.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, May 18, 1953
div1.opener:
May 18, 1953
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I certainly appreciate greatly the photographs and films. I will keep them
safely here and will make copies for the various American yellow fever per-
sonalities.

I am glad to know that you are going to the meeting of the American Medi-
cal Association in New York. I regret that I cannot go but my Colleagues,
Drs. Slocumb and Ward will be attending the meeting of the American
Rheumatism Association which will be the Friday and Saturday before the
meeting of the American Medical Association, May 29 and 30, in the Sert
Room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. You will be very welcome to attend
these meetings if you care to do so. Doctor Ward or Doctor Slocumb will
be presenting another summary of our own work.

It will be certainly fine if the Cuban Government would allow you to visit
around and present in person the Finlay Medals. I know that the recipients
were so pleased and one or two of them have inquired from me further. I have
written the enclosed note to Mr. Rodriguez. As you suggest, I have said
nothing of your excellent suggestion. It is a matter of fact that General
Truby, Mr. Lambert and Mr. Hanberry are all getting along in years. They
have written me wondering when they might hear further. Because of the
passing of time, I am making the following suggestion, not knowing whether
it can be carried out.

list.item:
1. General Reed and Blossom Reed - these could be presented by you with the
help of the Cuban Embassy in Washington but Blossom lives 90 miles from
Washington and would have to know a few days ahead of time in order to be
there for the ceremony. That would certainly be enough.
2. Henberry - did you plan to visit his home?

3. Dr. Cooke - did you plan to visit his home to present the posthumous
award to his widow and family?

item.p:
4. Lambert. His address is 17092 Lincoln Street, Hazel Crest, Illinois, a
suburb of Chicago. I had an idea. Would you prefer to have Lambert come to
the office of the Cuban Consul and do the matter simply there, or would
you like to have a little more of a ceremony which would bring more favorable
notice both to the recipient and to the giver, the Cuban Government. It
occurred to me that I have medical friends in Chicago (you may well have
also) at several hospitals and at both the University of Chicago and North-
western University Medical Schools. I am making an inquiry as to whether
there is a medical historical society in Chicago. There may well be but
of course the meeting of the A.M.A. is not in Chicago.

The ceremony might be a (1) very simple one at the Cuban consulate in Chicago
or (2) a simple one at the office of the American Medical Association (I
think they would be interested in it) or (3) a simple ceremony arranged to
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
- 2 -
May 18, 1953
be held at one of the medical schools or hospitals, the staff of the hos-
pital or the students of the medical school being invited. I know the
Professor of Medicine at Northern University. I have no idea how he would
react to the proposal but it seems to me that any medical school would
enjoy participating in such a ceremony. The participation could be simple
without much elaboration. I will not do anything about contacting the
A.M.A. or friends in Chicago until I hear from you but it may be that the
Cuban Consul General in Chicago would have to be consulted. You would
know more about that than I.

list.item:
5. General Truby and the Lazears in California. General Truby could not
go to Chicago or New York but Mrs. Briggs (Peggy Lazear) and General Truby
could receive the medal at an official ceremony either in General Truby's
home or perhaps at the Letterman Army Hospital where General Truby was
commanding officer. Certainly that would be a nice thing if they would
agree to it. Houston Lazear lives at Santa Barbara, California. He and
his wife are rather quiet and while they would tremendously appreciate
the honor, I doubt if they would go the whole way to San Francisco for
the ceremony. Perhaps they would. I must not speak for them.

div1.p: Let me know any way I can help.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosure
Copy sent to General Truby
